newsitem.title: UK: Lloyd's chairman to ring bell welcoming settlement.
newsitem.headline: Lloyd's chairman to ring bell welcoming settlement.

text.p: The chairman of the Lloyd's of London, David Rowland, will ring the Lutine bell at the centre of the market's underwriting room later on Wednesday to mark the UK's approval of its recovery plan, Lloyd's said in a statement.
UK trade minister Anthony Nelson will attend the ceremony after approving the plan which authorises the setting up of reinsurance vehicle Equitas to resolve past claims and losses.

The Lutine bell was traditionally rung once for bad news -- such as the loss of a ship at sea -- and twice for good news. "I think you will find he (Rowland) will ring the bell three times," a Lloyd's spokesman said.
The Lutine bell is named after the 18th century French frigate from which it was salvaged.
The symbol of the Lloyd's market, it hangs above a rostrum in the middle of the underwriting room at the heart of the modernistic Lloyd's building in London.
Government approval of Equitas marks the successful completion of Lloyd's reconstruction and renewal programme and secures the market's future.
